desc.size: Medium-sized tree, 12 - 20 m tall, trunk diameter 30 cm - 0.6 m. Trunk often leaning or crooked, extending to the top of the crown. Crown narrow, rounded, with many stout, straight branches.

part.partText: ashy gray, thin, fissured into soft, scaly plates that may flake off when rubbed.
stout, dark green, smooth, becoming light gray then dark gray and warty. Leaf scars oval, with several bundle scars forming a U.
bluish black, small, conical, finely hairy. Terminal bud 4 - 10 mm long, pointed. Uppermost pair of lateral buds up to 1 cm below the base of terminal bud.

opposite, pinnately compound, 25 - 40 cm long, with 7 - 11 leaflets. Leaflets stalkless (except for the terminal), dark green and smooth above, paler with rusty hairs along the veins beneath, 7 - 15 cm long, 2.5 - 5 cm wide, oblong to oblong lance-shaped, tapering or rounded at the base, long-pointed at the tip, margins toothed, thin, firm. Leaves turn reddish brown in autumn.
either male, female, or bisexual; usually found on separate trees, but sometimes on the same tree (polygamodioecious); borne in an elongated, branched inflorescence; purplish, small, without petals.
dry, single-seeded, winged (samara); in open, branched clusters; 2.5 - 4.5 cm long, oblong, barely notched at the tip; wing broad, often twisted, extending near the base of the flat seed cavity.

similarSpecies.comments: Fraxinus nigra is best identified by having unstalked leaflets, thin, ashy gray bark fissured into soft, scaly plates, and fruit with a broad, often twisted wing extending near the base of the flat seed cavity. Fraxinus americana has short-stalked leaflets with pale or whitish undersides, twigs with raised leaf scars, fruit with large seed cavities having a wing which doesn’t extend to the base, and a flaky, scaly, or peeling twig epidermis (except current year’s growth). Fraxinus pennsylvanica may have densely hairy shoots, and the wing of its fruit encloses half or more of the seed cavity. Fraxinus profunda has conspicuously stalked leaflets, densely hairy shoots (current), and fruit with a wing often extending to the base of the seed cavity. Fraxinus quadrangulata has square twigs, and fruit with a wing extending to and around the base of the seed cavity.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Local in moist woods, swamps, fens, floodplains, and other mesic sites. However, its most characteristic habitat is on calcareous springy slopes.

notes.comments: The wood of Fraxinus nigra is used for baskets, barrel hoops, woven chair bottoms, fence posts, cabinets, interior finish, and furniture. The emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis) is a serious insect threat to all native ashes (see link below).

etymology.comments: Fraxinus is the Latin word for ash. Nigra is Latin for black, referring to its dark brown heartwood.
